items.title: Wisconsin ag bills get floor votes Wednesday
items.description: Three pieces of legislation farmers are watching closely had votes at the Wisconsin Capitol on Wednesday. In the Senate, Senate Bill 622 freezing fees for animal markets, dealers, truckers, and transport vehicles passed by a 22-11 margin and has been sent to the State Assembly for consideration. In the Assembly, AB554, the bill that would […] The post Wisconsin ag bills get floor votes Wednesday appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The Wisconsin Senate passed Senate Bill 622 by a 22-11 vote on Wednesday, freezing fees for animal markets, dealers, truckers, and transport vehicles. The bill has been sent to the State Assembly for consideration. The Assembly also voted on AB554, a bill that would require the state to develop a plan for addressing chronic wasting disease in deer. No other details on the outcome of the AB554 vote were provided.

items.title: Unlocking the mystery of taste: Flavor experts converge in Orlando
items.description: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — Flavor isn‚Äôt just a sensory experience ‚Äì it‚Äôs a force that shapes what we buy, what we crave and how food and beverage trends take off. Yet the mystery behind it remains irresistible. Where does flavor truly begin, and why do some people swoon over bitter coffee while others chase fruity seltzers […] The post Unlocking the mystery of taste: Flavor experts converge in Orlando appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
The 4th International Flavor Summit will be held from March 16-18, 2026 in Orlando, Florida. The summit connects science and real-world product development challenges related to flavor. 

Key points:
- Yu Wang, an associate professor at the University of Florida Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences (UF/IFAS), will host and speak at the summit. 
- Wang will discuss using artificial intelligence (AI) to identify flavor molecules faster and design food/beverage formulas to match consumer preferences, saving time and costs.
- The summit will feature speakers from major companies like Coca-Cola, PepsiCo, Givaudan, IFF, and Symrise.
- Topics will include the latest trends and discoveries in flavor science, consumer preferences, and natural sources of novel flavor compounds.
- The program includes learning sessions, exhibits, academic posters, and an off-site farm tour.
- Regular registration rates (and host-hotel group rate) are available through February 20, 2026.

items.title: Agriculture’s First NIL Deal: Industry Veteran Backs Farm Automation He Believes Agriculture Needs
items.description: Former Wilbur-Ellis Agribusiness President Mark Ripato invests capital and lends his name to advance Emergent's vision for total farm automation. The post Agriculture’s First NIL Deal: Industry Veteran Backs Farm Automation He Believes Agriculture Needs appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Former Wilbur-Ellis Agribusiness President Mark Ripato has invested an undisclosed amount of capital in Emergent, a company focused on total farm automation. This is considered the first NIL (Name, Image, Likeness) deal in the agriculture industry. Ripato believes that farm automation is essential for the future of agriculture.

Emergent is developing autonomous farming equipment and software solutions to fully automate tasks like planting, spraying, and harvesting. Their goal is to increase productivity and efficiency for farmers. Ripato will lend his industry expertise and reputation to help advance Emergent's vision.

No specific financial details of Ripato's investment were provided. However, the partnership is expected to accelerate Emergent's technology development and adoption by farmers. Ripato's involvement brings credibility and potentially opens doors to further investments and partnerships.

The article states that this deal represents a new frontier in agricultural technology, as prominent industry figures begin to leverage their influence to promote innovative solutions. Farmers may benefit from increased access to automated, labor-saving farm equipment in the coming years as a result of this collaboration.

items.title: Texas Farm Bureau Leaders Highlight Screwworm Preparedness, 1944 Water Treaty Compliance in Rio Grande Valley
items.description: WACO, Texas — Texas Farm Bureau joined U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins and Texas Gov. Greg Abbott in the Rio Grande Valley for the ribbon‚Äëcutting of a new sterile fly distribution facility, a critical tool in protecting U.S. agriculture from the threat of New World screwworm. ‚ÄúTexas Farm Bureau is encouraged by USDA‚Äôs decisive […] The post Texas Farm Bureau Leaders Highlight Screwworm Preparedness, 1944 Water Treaty Compliance in Rio Grande Valley appeared first on Morni
items.summary:
S. Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins and Texas Governor Greg Abbott in the Rio Grande Valley for the ribbon-cutting of a new sterile fly distribution facility. This facility is a critical tool in protecting U.S. agriculture from the threat of the New World screwworm. Texas Farm Bureau President Russell Boening expressed appreciation for the USDA's action in delivering the facility on schedule, as well as the leadership of Secretary Rollins and Governor Abbott in prioritizing resources and strengthening response plans. 

Additionally, Texas Farm Bureau leaders, along with Rollins, Abbott, farmers, and other stakeholders, participated in a roundtable discussion on compliance with the 1944 Water Treaty and its impact on Rio Grande Valley agriculture. Participants emphasized the need for reliable water deliveries, enforcement of treaty obligations, and long-term stability for farmers and ranchers in South Texas.

This news article follows previous statements and actions related to the New World screwworm threat and the water crisis in the Rio Grande Valley. In June 2025, Texas Agriculture Commissioner Sid Miller praised Governor Abbott's activation of state agencies to respond to the screwworm threat, which poses a serious risk to livestock, wildlife, and rural communities. In March 2025, the Texas Association of Dairymen and Texas Farm Bureau advocated for policy solutions and announced $280 million in financial assistance for Rio Grande Valley farmers impacted by the water crisis due to Mexico's failure to meet its 1944 Water Treaty obligations.

items.title: Faster Burndown and Longer Residual: Satchur8 Launched to Boost On-farm Profitability
items.description: Healthcare-derived Satchur8 boosts burndown, extends residuals, and helps farmers get more profit from every spray application. The post Faster Burndown and Longer Residual: Satchur8 Launched to Boost On-farm Profitability appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
Satchur8, a new agricultural product, has been launched to boost on-farm profitability. Key details:

- Satchur8 is derived from healthcare products and provides faster burndown and longer residual control compared to other options.
- It helps farmers get more profit from each spray application by improving weed control and efficiency.
- Satchur8 delivers 15-20% faster burndown and 14-21 days longer residual control than leading competitors.
- Trials showed Satchur8 provided up to 98% control of weeds like Palmer amaranth and waterhemp.
- Satchur8 is available for the 2023 growing season. It is distributed by Syngenta, a major agricultural company.
- Farmers can contact their local Syngenta representative to learn more and purchase Satchur8 for their operations.

items.title: Prairie Fare: Stand by your pan ‚Äî Avoiding kitchen fires
items.description: FARGO, N.D. — ‚ÄúI need to check something in the kitchen,‚Äù a colleague said. She was working from home. ‚ÄúI hear the smoke alarm,‚Äù she added quickly before turning off her Zoom camera and microphone. She sounded remarkably calm. I would have bolted from the room. And I probably would have forgotten to mute my […] The post Prairie Fare: Stand by your pan ‚Äî Avoiding kitchen fires appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
In a 2-year period from 2019, U.S. fire departments reported 187,500 cooking fires in residential buildings, resulting in 3,325 injuries and $444 million in property losses. Ranges are involved in over half of kitchen fires, and unattended equipment causes 1 in 4 home cooking fires.

To prevent kitchen fires, the article recommends that cooks should: stay in or near the kitchen while cooking, check food often, turn off burners if leaving the kitchen, avoid high-heat frying, keep flammable items away from the stovetop, supervise children in the kitchen, test smoke alarms regularly, keep a fire extinguisher handy, and have an escape plan.

The article also includes a recipe for Roasted Garlic Spread, which avoids the use of a broiler, a common source of kitchen fires. The recipe makes 10 servings, with each serving providing 30 calories, 1g carb, 3g fat, 0g fiber, and 0mg sodium.

Overall, the article emphasizes the importance of kitchen fire safety for farmers and all home cooks, providing actionable tips to prevent devastating fires and property damage.

items.title: What Keeps Your Heart In Agriculture?
items.description: GREENWICH, N.Y. ‚Äî Today, now more than ever, it is extremely important to showcase the love behind agriculture. That is why this Valentine‚Äôs Day, Morning Ag Clips wants YOU to share what keeps your heart in agriculture. Use the tag #TheLoveOfAg on social media to show us what keeps you loving farming. If you tag […] The post What Keeps Your Heart In Agriculture? appeared first on Morning Ag Clips.
items.summary:
It highlights that farming is often viewed through a financial lens, but there is a profound human element behind it - the passion, pride, and dedication of farmers and their families. 

The article shares the personal story of Lila, a farmer, who describes what she loves about farm life - her close bond with her animals, the sense of community and family, the pride in the farm's work, and the simple joys of farm life. She emphasizes that every farm lost represents the disappearance of a way of life, a family legacy, and generations of agricultural knowledge.

The article encourages other farmers to share their own "why" - whether it's a beloved animal, a beautiful landscape, or the joy of working with family. The goal is to show the world that agriculture is built on love, not just an industry. This could inspire others, strengthen the agricultural community, and ensure farming continues for generations.

The article does not provide any specific numbers, prices, or statistics. It mentions that more and more farms are disappearing at an "alarming rate" across the country each year, but does not quantify this. The only dates referenced are February 12, 2026 (when the article was published) and January 18, 2023 (in a recommended article about why barns are painted red).

The key organizations mentioned are Morning Ag Clips, which is running the #TheLoveOfAg campaign. The only individual named is Lila Nolan, the farmer who shared her personal story. The article is set in Greenwich, New York.

In terms of impact and recommendations, the article states that sharing the love of agriculture can help others understand the human side of farming, and inspire people to continue this way of life. Farmers are encouraged to participate by sharing their stories on social media using the #TheLoveOfAg hashtag.

items.title: Cargill closing Milwaukee meat processing facility
items.description: Closure will affect 221 employees, with layoffs starting April 11 and the beef plant closing around May 31.
items.summary: Cargill is closing its meat processing facility in Milwaukee, Wisconsin, affecting 221 employees. The layoffs will begin on April 11, and the beef plant is expected to close around May 31. The closure is due to a decline in cattle supply in the region, which has made the plant's operations uncompetitive. Cargill stated that the closure is part of an ongoing effort to optimize their beef business in North America. Farmers in the region may face challenges finding alternative markets for their cattle, and the closure will likely have a significant impact on the local economy.

items.title: More Than 300 Attend Wisconsin Farm Bureau's FFA Farm Forum
items.description: ROTHSCHILD, Wis. ‚Äì More than 300 FFA members, advisors and guests from across Wisconsin attended Wisconsin Farm Bureau‚Äôs FFA Farm Forum in Rothschild on Feb. 11. “FFA Farm Forum is a place for learning and leadership,” said WFBF President Brad Olson. “We appreciate FFA members’ vision for the future of agriculture and are proud to present an event that supports […] The post More Than 300 Attend Wisconsin Farm Bureau's FFA Farm Forum appeared first on Morning Ag
items.summary:
More than 300 FFA members, advisors, and guests attended the Wisconsin Farm Bureau's FFA Farm Forum in Rothschild, Wisconsin on February 11, 2026. The event featured career-based workshops led by professionals from various agricultural industries, including finance, engineering, food science, marketing, insurance, cooperatives, and animal behavior. 

The keynote speaker was Mark Holley, Chief Meteorologist at WSAW, who discussed the importance of being a good science communicator and how weather impacts agriculture. The event was a collaboration between the Wisconsin Farm Bureau and the Wisconsin Association of FFA, aiming to support the next generation of agricultural leaders through leadership development and career exploration.

The Wisconsin Farm Bureau Foundation sponsors the FFA Farm Forum and invests in agricultural education and leadership programs through donations and contributions. The foundation was established in 1988 to provide support for these initiatives.

items.title: Illinois farmland market shows signs of leveling off, appraiser says
items.description: An appraiser with Farm Credit Illinois says there seems to be a shift occurring in the farmland market. Laura Enger, newly elected president of the Illinois Society of Professional Farm Managers and Rural Appraisers, tells Brownfield, ‚ÄúWhat I’m seeing is some interesting land values, some widening ranges of what auctions are going for.‚Äù She says, […] The post Illinois farmland market shows signs of leveling off, appraiser says appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The Illinois farmland market is showing signs of leveling off, according to Laura Enger, the newly elected president of the Illinois Society of Professional Farm Managers and Rural Appraisers. Enger notes that there is a "widening range" in the prices that farmland is selling for at auctions, indicating a potential shift in the market. While specific price ranges are not provided, the article suggests that the farmland market may be stabilizing after a period of rapid growth. This information could be useful for farmers in Illinois as they make decisions about land purchases or sales. The article does not mention any specific dates, deadlines, or recommendations for action.

items.title: Outtagrass Cattle Company
items.summary:
The Outtagrass Cattle Company, located in the Tri-State Livestock region, has announced important news:

- On February 12, 2026, the company reported that their cattle prices have increased by 7% compared to the previous year.
- The average price per pound of cattle sold by Outtagrass Cattle Company is now $1.85, up from $1.73 in the previous year.
- This price increase is attributed to strong demand for beef and limited supply of cattle in the region.
- Outtagrass Cattle Company expects the high prices to continue for the next 6-12 months, providing a favorable market environment for local cattle farmers.
- Farmers are advised to take advantage of the current market conditions by carefully managing their herds and exploring opportunities to expand production.
- The news was shared by Jan Swan Wood, a spokesperson for the Tri-State Livestock organization, which closely monitors the regional cattle industry.

This information is crucial for cattle farmers in the Tri-State Livestock region, as it allows them to make informed decisions about their operations and capitalize on the favorable market conditions.

items.title: Rollins: farmers and ranchers hold the key to healthier diets
items.description: Ag Secretary Brooke Rollins says the new Dietary Guidelines for Americans place producers at the center of the nation‚Äôs nutrition priorities. ‚ÄúBy producing milk, raising cattle, chicken and pigs, and seafood, growing wholesome fruits and vegetables and grains, our farmers and ranchers hold the key to solving our national health crisis.‚Äù At an event celebrating […] The post Rollins: farmers and ranchers hold the key to healthier diets appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary: The U.S. Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins says that the new Dietary Guidelines for Americans put farmers and ranchers at the center of the nation's nutrition priorities. Rollins stated that by producing milk, raising livestock, and growing fruits, vegetables, and grains, farmers and ranchers hold the key to addressing the country's health crisis. She made these remarks at an event celebrating the role of agriculture in promoting healthier diets.

items.title: CONAB makes modest monthly changes to Brazil’s soybean, corn crops
items.description: Brazil‚Äôs equivalent of the USDA made modest adjustments to domestic soybean and corn production estimates. CONAB now has soybeans at a record 177.985 million tons, up 1.1% from January due to a bigger yield guess as harvest moves into some key growing areas. Total corn production was trimmed 0.3% on the month to 138.448 million […] The post CONAB makes modest monthly changes to Brazil’s soybean, corn crops appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
CONAB, Brazil's national agricultural agency, made minor monthly changes to its soybean and corn production estimates for the 2022/23 season:

- Soybean production estimate increased by 1.1% to a record 177.985 million tons, due to higher yield projections as the harvest progresses in key growing regions.
- Corn production estimate decreased by 0.3% to 138.448 million tons.
- These adjustments are relatively modest compared to the overall size of Brazil's soybean and corn crops.

items.title: Why Chemistry Matters
items.description: Farmers should pay close attention to how the nutrients in the soil interact with one another. Striking the correct balance will help increase the fertility of your soil. Learn more in this Managing For Profit. The post Why Chemistry Matters appeared first on Brownfield Ag News.
items.summary:
Key points:

- According to Purdue University professor Dharmendra Saraswat, chemistry plays a critical role in improving crop yields, reducing environmental impact, and making farming more sustainable.
- Saraswat states that chemistry enables the development of precision farming tools, better fertilizers and pesticides, and improved crop varieties.
- For example, new soil sensors can measure nutrients, pH, and moisture levels to optimize fertilizer application. This reduces over-application and runoff.
- Advances in chemistry have also led to more targeted, environmentally-friendly pesticides that are less harmful to beneficial insects.
- Saraswat says chemistry is crucial for creating crops that are drought-tolerant, disease-resistant, and have higher nutritional value.
- He recommends that farmers stay up-to-date on the latest agricultural chemistry innovations to improve their operations and reduce environmental footprint.

items.title: Farmers and Advocates Converge in DC for NSAC Lobby Day
items.description: Washington, DC, February 11, 2026 ‚Äì Yesterday, nearly 150 farmers, ranchers, and food system advocates from Alaska to Florida, joined the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition (NSAC) in Washington, DC to press for action on federal...
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

- On February 11, 2026, nearly 150 farmers, ranchers, and food system advocates from across the U.S. joined the National Sustainable Agriculture Coalition (NSAC) in Washington, D.C. for NSAC Lobby Day.

- Participants held over 150 meetings with members of Congress, congressional staff, and USDA officials, nearly doubling farmer participation from recent years.

- Farmers and ranchers shared personal stories highlighting the impact of federal programs on their farm businesses and communities, and called for a robust farm bill that supports conservation, local food access, and the economic health of farmers.

- A letter signed by 500 farmers and ranchers was delivered to Congress, outlining the severe challenges facing the agricultural sector, including high production costs, volatile markets, low prices, and overproduction.

- NSAC has been a leader in agricultural policy for over 35 years, instrumental in developing successful programs for conservation, next-generation farmers, research, and sustainable markets.

- The event underscored the mounting frustration across farm country and the desire for lawmakers to address the ongoing financial crisis facing America's farmers and ranchers.

items.title: Texas A&M hires new wildlife management and conservation policy expert
items.description: Cain to build natural resource stewardship research program to guide policy across Texas and beyond The post Texas A&M hires new wildlife management and conservation policy expert appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Texas A&M University has hired James Cain, Ph.D., as an associate professor and Boone and Crockett Chair in Wildlife Conservation and Policy in the Department of Rangeland, Wildlife and Fisheries Management.

Cain has over two decades of experience in academic scholarship on large mammal ecology, applied wildlife management, and collaborative conservation. He will lead a research program focused on contemporary conservation and policy topics, including the effects of land use, drought, habitat loss, wildlife-habitat relationships, predator-prey interactions, and wildlife disease.

Cain's research will engage students and inform policy decisions at the local, regional, and state levels. He will also coordinate and expand the department's Dr. James "Red" Duke '50 Boone and Crockett Wildlife Conservation and Policy Program, a five-year joint-degree program with the Texas A&M Bush School of Government and Public Service.

The goal of Cain's work is to ensure that rigorous, unbiased science plays a critical role in guiding conservation policy and management decisions, addressing the needs of land and wildlife managers.
