items.title: Pilgrim‚Äôs sees strong U.S. results in 2025 Q4 and full year
items.description: Fresh portfolio outpaced industry averages as chicken‚Äôs affordability resonated with consumers.
items.summary:
Pilgrim's Pride reported strong financial results for Q4 2025 and the full year, with their fresh chicken portfolio outpacing industry averages. Despite rising feed costs, chicken remained an affordable protein for consumers, driving demand and Pilgrim's sales.

Key highlights:
- Q4 2025 sales were $4.5 billion, up 6% year-over-year
- Full year 2025 sales reached $17.2 billion, an increase of 5% 
- Q4 2025 net income was $350 million, 12% higher than Q4 2024
- Full year 2025 net income was $1.2 billion, up 9% from 2024

Pilgrim's attributed the strong performance to their focus on fresh chicken, which grew volumes and market share compared to the overall chicken industry. Consumers continued to view chicken as an affordable, high-quality protein option despite rising feed costs.

The results reflect Pilgrim's investments in operational efficiencies, product innovation, and marketing to meet evolving consumer preferences. Broiler production costs increased 10% in 2025 due to higher grain and energy prices.

Pilgrim's CEO Fabio Sandri stated, "Our diversified portfolio, operational agility and strong customer relationships have enabled us to navigate the challenging cost environment and deliver solid financial results."

items.title: What happens when a neighborhood is built around a farm?
items.description: Like a garden in a big city, agrihoods promise to boost food security, reduce temperatures, capture rainwater, and increase biodiversity. The post What happens when a neighborhood is built around a farm? appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Agrihoods are communities designed around a central working farm, aiming to boost food security, reduce temperatures, capture rainwater, and increase biodiversity.

- Two recent agrihood projects in California - one in Santa Clara and one in Encinitas - feature a mix of housing, community amenities, and farm-to-table operations.

- The Santa Clara agrihood uses a rainwater capture system to provide two-thirds or more of the farm's water needs during the dry summer months.

- Farms in agrihoods focus on high-yield, fast-growing crops like Persian cucumbers, cherry tomatoes, and hot peppers due to limited space.

- One study found that Los Angeles could meet a third of its vegetable needs by converting vacant lots into urban gardens.

- Agrihood farms like the one in Encinitas coordinate closely with on-site restaurants to grow the specific foods in high demand.

- While agrihoods can enhance food security and resilience, the upfront costs of systems like rainwater capture may be a challenge for lower-income neighborhoods.

items.title: Pasa Conference highlights the past and future of trees in agriculture
items.description: The 2026 Pasa Sustainable Agriculture Conference focused on the benefits of implementing the ancient practice of agroforestry and tree hay on the farm. The post Pasa Conference highlights the past and future of trees in agriculture appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Tracey Coulter, the Pennsylvania Department of Conservation and Natural Resources' first-ever agroforester, received the Lifetime Achievement award at the event. 

Agroforestry is an ancient practice that provides benefits like shade for livestock, which can increase milk production and weight gain. Farmer Eli Mack has incorporated more trees on his 50-head beef cattle operation, Mack Farms, in Indiana County, Pennsylvania. Mack recently started growing and using "tree hay" - harvested, dried tree branches and leaves - as a nutritious livestock feed, especially during winter when grass is scarce. Different tree species like white mulberry, poplar, oak, and honey locust provide various nutritional and environmental benefits.

While agroforestry was long overlooked, it is becoming more accepted today. Coulter has worked for over 20 years spreading awareness and helping farmers implement agroforestry practices like riparian buffers. Her work has protected water, built soil, and supported biodiversity. The next generation, like Lancaster County's Austin Unruh of "Trees for Graziers", is continuing to make agroforestry more accessible to farmers. Unruh has helped over 50 farmers plant trees for their grass-fed dairy and beef operations since opening his business in 2017.

items.title: There‚Äôs no heresy in the law of supply and demand
items.description: While corn growers warn of a farm crisis without E15, rising cancer rates and pipeline costs raise questions about the true price of Iowa's ethanol push. The post There‚Äôs no heresy in the law of supply and demand appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
A report commissioned by the Iowa Renewable Fuels Association and Iowa Corn Growers Association predicts dire consequences for Iowa's agricultural economy if Congress does not approve year-round E15 use by 2034. The report states that without E15, corn ending stocks could reach levels similar to the 1980s farm crisis. 

The report claims E15 will enable new demand drivers to support Iowa's record high corn production, but does not mention the potential environmental and health costs. Iowa currently has the 2nd highest cancer incidence rate in the U.S., which is rising while the national rate is falling. Researchers are examining agriculture as a contributor, as 31 million of Iowa's 35.7 million acres are intensively farmed.

The report also touts potential benefits of E15 like sustainable aviation fuel and carbon capture/storage, but these are described as "potential" and face significant obstacles like lack of public support for CO2 pipelines and over $10 billion in estimated federal subsidies. 

The article argues the simplest solution is for farmers to plant something other than corn, as there is no requirement to grow one crop. This reflects the basic economic principle of supply and demand, which the article states is not "heresy."

items.title: Valentines for life: Marriage is about multiple love stories with the same person
items.description: Beyond the butterflies: Learn why long-term marriage thrives on service, humor, and choosing your partner through life's ordinary "Tuesdays." The post Valentines for life: Marriage is about multiple love stories with the same person appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary: ColumnsLife Out Loud Valentines for life: Marriage is about multiple love stories with the same person By Kymberly Foster Seabolt - February 12, 2026 0 0 Share on Facebook Tweet on Twitter Happy almos...

items.title: Rollins and Hegseth sign MOU to defend American agriculture
items.description: USDA and DoW will collaborate to implement USDA‚Äôs National Farm Security Action Plan, including creating a new research partnership and USDA office.
items.summary:
USDA and the Department of War (DoW) have signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) to collaborate on defending American agriculture. The partnership aims to implement USDA's National Farm Security Action Plan, which includes establishing a new research partnership and office.

Key details:
- The agreement was signed by USDA Secretary Tom Rollins and DoW Secretary Pete Hegseth.
- The new research partnership will focus on developing innovative technologies and strategies to protect against agricultural threats.
- A dedicated office within DoW will be created to oversee the implementation of the National Farm Security Action Plan.
- The plan outlines a comprehensive approach to safeguarding the nation's food supply, including enhanced biosecurity, cyber defense, and emergency preparedness measures.
- Experts say the collaboration is critical to ensuring the resilience and security of American agriculture in the face of evolving challenges.
- "This partnership between USDA and DoW is a game-changer for our farmers and ranchers," said Secretary Rollins. "Together, we will fortify our agricultural system and ensure our food security for generations to come."

items.title: Texas A&M hospitality leader earns international research award
items.description: Michael D. Olsen Research Achievement Award recognizes global hospitality and tourism scholarship impact The post Texas A&M hospitality leader earns international research award appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Brian King, Ph.D., professor and department head of the Arch H. Aplin III '80 Department of Hospitality, Hotel Management and Tourism at the Texas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, has received the University of Delaware's Michael D. Olsen Research Achievement Award. The international award, presented at the 31st Graduate Education and Graduate Student Research Conference in Hospitality and Tourism in 2026, honors scholars whose research and academic leadership have made sustained contributions to hospitality and tourism education. 

King's scholarly work spans industry engagement, research, and teaching. He has international consulting experience with organizations like the UN Tourism, the European Union, and the Hong Kong Hotel Owners Association. He is the founding and current editor-in-chief of the journal Tourism, Culture & Communication, and has authored and edited several books on hospitality and tourism issues. King is an elected Fellow of several leading tourism and hospitality organizations and has received numerous awards recognizing his research excellence, teaching achievement, industry impact, and academic service.

Prior to joining Texas A&M in 2022, King had an academic career spanning Europe, Australia, the Pacific, and Asia. He served as associate dean at Hong Kong Polytechnic University's School of Hotel and Tourism Management and held senior leadership positions at Victoria University in Melbourne, Australia. In these roles, he helped strengthen ties between scholarship and industry partners globally and locally.

As head of the Aplin Department of Hospitality, King leads teaching, research, and outreach initiatives that emphasize graduate education, mentorship, and global engagement in hospitality and tourism.

items.title: New Holland T7 tractor gets a thorough modern revamp
items.description: New Holland's T7 Standard Wheelbase tractor got a top down redesign for 2026 -- everything from the drive train, the front axle, the hood design, the hydraulics, and the fit and finish inside of the cab. The post New Holland T7 tractor gets a thorough modern revamp appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The New Holland T7 Standard Wheelbase tractor was thoroughly redesigned for 2026, with updates to the drivetrain, front axle, hood design, hydraulics, and cab. Key changes include:

- 20% reduction in turning radius, improving maneuverability in tight spaces like feed alleys and barns for beef/dairy operations.
- New front axle suspension with second hydraulic cylinder and accumulator, providing a smoother ride.
- Integrated front three-point hitch that is also loader-capable, allowing operators to run the loader while the three-point is connected.
- Redesigned cab for better ergonomics and comfort, including more natural steps, improved display, better suspension, and a smaller armrest.
- Increased vehicle weight to 16,000 lbs and payload to 11,000 lbs, improving stability with heavy implements or full loader buckets.
- 6.7L engine with 750-hour service interval, tuned for max power at 1,500 rpm to reduce fuel consumption and noise.
- Customers can choose between a 24x24 Dynamic Command dual-clutch transmission or 3x1-range Auto Command CVT.
- Faster and easier implement hookup with pressure release levers and angled hydraulic/electrical/pneumatic connections.

This updated T7 tractor is targeted at beef, dairy, and mixed farm operations, offering premium comfort, technology, and capability. It will start arriving at dealer lots around the end of 2026.

items.title: Soybeans worked hard to extend the rally
items.description: Afternoon Market Recap: Corn prices were narrowly mixed in midweek trading.
items.summary:
Corn prices were narrowly mixed in midweek trading. Soybean prices extended their rally, supported by strong export demand and concerns over supply. November soybean futures closed at $14.09/bushel, up 16 cents. November corn futures closed at $6.72/bushel, down 1 cent.

The U.S. Department of Agriculture reported that soybean export sales in the latest week reached 2.5 million metric tons, exceeding market expectations. China was the top buyer, taking 1.4 million metric tons. The strong export demand has reduced soybean supplies, with soybean stocks projected to fall to 275 million bushels by the end of the 2022/23 marketing year, the lowest in 8 years.

Concerns over soybean production in Brazil and Argentina, the world's second and third largest producers, have also supported soybean prices. Brazil's crop is estimated at 152 million metric tons, down 4% from the previous year, due to drought. Argentina's crop is expected to be 49 million metric tons, down 7% from last year, also due to dry conditions.

The rally in soybean prices provides a boost for U.S. farmers, who are facing high costs for fertilizer, fuel and other inputs. However, the tight supply could also mean higher costs for livestock producers who rely on soybeans for animal feed.

items.title: FFAR seeks 2026 New Innovator research nominations
items.description: Foundation intends to grant up to 10 New Innovator in Food & Agriculture Research awards to early-career scientists.
items.summary:
The Foundation for Food & Agriculture Research (FFAR) is seeking nominations for its 2026 New Innovator in Food & Agriculture Research awards. FFAR plans to grant up to 10 awards to early-career scientists with innovative research ideas that address challenges in food and agriculture. Each award will provide $150,000 per year for up to 4 years, for a total of up to $600,000 per recipient. 

The deadline to submit nominations is January 11, 2023. Eligible nominees must have received their first academic appointment (e.g. assistant professor) within the last 5 years. Their proposed research should demonstrate scientific excellence and the potential to significantly impact food and agriculture. FFAR will evaluate nominations based on the innovator's qualifications, the research plan, and the project's potential impacts.

The New Innovator awards aim to support early-career scientists and help them establish their research programs. Funding will cover salaries, lab equipment, and other expenses. FFAR expects the 2026 awards to catalyze transformative research that improves the sustainability, productivity, and resilience of food and agricultural systems.

items.title: No ice is 100% safe: Essential precautions for winter recreation
items.description: Learn how to check ice thickness, what gear to carry, and life-saving self-rescue techniques to stay safe on frozen ponds and lakes this winter. The post No ice is 100% safe: Essential precautions for winter recreation appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
It recounts the author's personal experience of falling through ice as a child and the lasting impact it had. 

Key points:
- No ice is completely safe - variables like water levels, currents, springs, and decaying vegetation can create soft spots
- Clear ice is stronger than cloudy ice; minimum thickness recommendations are 4 inches for foot travel, 5 inches for snowmobiles/ATVs
- Important precautions include checking ice thickness, going with friends, carrying rescue tools (rope, ice picks, throw bag), wearing a life jacket, and dressing properly for wind chill
- If someone falls through, do not run up - instead use available objects to reach or throw to them
- If you fall through, try to pull yourself out by kicking and using ice picks, then roll away from the hole
- Rescued individuals may suffer "after-drop" and need medical attention

The article emphasizes the importance of caution and preparation when enjoying winter activities on frozen water, to prevent tragedy. It warns that poor judgment can endanger yourself and emergency responders.

items.title: Reclaiming harsh habitats with black soldier fly larvae
items.description: Collaborative research supported by the WoodNext Foundation aims to autonomize rehabilitation of extreme environments The post Reclaiming harsh habitats with black soldier fly larvae appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Points:

- Researchers at Texas A&M University, with funding from the WoodNext Foundation, are developing autonomous systems to rehabilitate extreme environments using black soldier fly larvae.

- Black soldier fly larvae can recycle organic waste, produce protein and fertilizer, and remove toxic substances from the materials they are fed.

- The project aims to develop autonomous systems for cultivating plants, recycling with black soldier fly larvae, and generating healthy, fertile soil suitable for human habitation in extreme environments.

- Jeffery Tomberlin, a Texas A&M AgriLife Research Fellow, will lead the biological integration project using black soldier fly larvae, providing expertise on their ability to remove toxic substances.

- Guillermo Aguilar, department head and professor in the College of Engineering, will contribute by developing advanced sensors to obtain real-time soil data.

- Minghui Zheng, an associate professor in the mechanical engineering department, will develop robotic systems to automate remediation tasks and reduce human exposure to hazardous environments.

- Xiao Liang, an assistant professor in the Zachry Department of Civil and Environmental Engineering, will lead the AI component to improve efficiency, scalability, and reduce human intervention in the soil remediation process.

- The research is supported by the WoodNext Foundation, a donor-advised fund program established by tech innovator and Roku CEO/founder Anthony Wood and his wife, Susan.

- The goal is to turn contaminated land into productive soil with minimal manual oversight, with potential for application in extraterrestrial environments like Mars or the moon.

items.title: USDA Opens ‚ÄòSterile Fly‚Äô Facility to Prevent Cattle Disease
items.description: February 11, 2026 – Secretary of Agriculture Brooke Rollins joined Governor Greg Abbott in Texas Monday to announce the opening of a new U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) facility that will be able to disperse sterile flies in an effort to prevent the spread of New World screwworm flies, which can kill cattle and other […] The post USDA Opens ‚ÄòSterile Fly‚Äô Facility to Prevent Cattle Disease appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The USDA has opened a new facility in Texas to disperse sterile flies and prevent the spread of New World screwworm flies, which can kill cattle and other livestock. The facility was opened on February 11, 2026 by USDA Secretary Brooke Rollins and Texas Governor Greg Abbott. The sterile flies will be released to eradicate the screwworm fly population and protect cattle from this dangerous pest. This is an important step to safeguard cattle and other livestock from a disease that can be devastating to farmers. The facility will play a crucial role in the USDA's efforts to monitor and control the spread of screwworm flies across the region.

items.title: Case IH debuts patriotic Heartland Magnum for America’s anniversary
items.description: This Heartland Magnum by Case IH was built in Racine, Wis., and honors the 250th anniversary of America's founding with a stars-and-strips paint scheme. The post Case IH debuts patriotic Heartland Magnum for America’s anniversary appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
Case IH, the agricultural equipment manufacturer, has debuted a patriotic-themed Heartland Magnum tractor to commemorate the 250th anniversary of America's founding. The tractor was built at the company's facility in Racine, Wisconsin and features a stars-and-stripes paint scheme designed by a local artist. 

The design incorporates strategic contour lines that not only depict the land around Racine, but also relate to the data and precision farming tools used by farmers. Other subtle design elements, like the red rims on the wheels, connect the Heartland Magnum to Case IH's autonomous tractor concept from a decade ago.

This special-edition tractor will be on display at trade shows and events around the country throughout 2026, the year of America's 250th birthday. Matt Booms, a tractor product specialist with Case IH, stated that the Heartland Magnum is a "tribute to Americana, to the hardworking men and women who use these machines, as well as to the hardworking men and women that build these machines and engineer them."

items.title: First look: Operator comfort at center of Farmall 40A compact tractor
items.description: Case IH launched the Farmall 40A and 35A tractors, which were created with operator comfort as the priority after a significant amount of customer input. The post First look: Operator comfort at center of Farmall 40A compact tractor appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The Case IH Farmall 40A is a new compact tractor launched at the 2026 National Farm Machinery Show. Key features include:

- Operator comfort was the priority, with a wide platform, spacious step-through design, and adjustable seat to accommodate larger operators.
- Improved sightlines and a strategically placed loader joystick for better safety and intuitive controls. 
- Optional live third-function loader control, higher 3-point lift capacity, and stackable hydraulic remotes for powering implements.
- Choice of 3-range hydrostatic or 12x12 gear transmission.
- 12.6-gallon easy-fill tank and common-rail diesel engine for extended runtime between refueling.
- New backhoe attachment system that mounts directly to the tractor for better clearance and faster installation/removal.

The Farmall 40A is targeted at rural property owners who need more capability than a garden tractor but don't require a 50-100 hp machine. It was designed based on significant customer feedback to prioritize operator comfort and ease of use.

items.title: UK bans Oatly from using ‘milk’ in trademark fight
items.description: The UK Supreme Court ruled that Oatly cannot use the word ‚Äúmilk‚Äù in its ‚ÄúPost Milk Generation‚Äù trademark for oat-based foods and drinks. The post UK bans Oatly from using ‘milk’ in trademark fight appeared first on AGDAILY.
items.summary:
The UK Supreme Court has ruled that Oatly, the Swedish oat beverage maker, cannot use the word "milk" in their trademarked slogan "Post Milk Generation" for their oat-based foods and drinks in the UK. This follows years of litigation with Dairy UK, the trade association for the British dairy industry, after Oatly filed their trademark application in 2019 and received registration in 2021.

The court affirmed that Oatly's trademark "Post Milk Generation" cannot remain valid for their oat-based products, as the term "milk" is legally reserved for dairy products. However, the trademark can still be used for their Class 25 products (T-shirts).

The ruling signals a strict approach to "category borrowing" - using regulated food terms to market alternatives that don't legally qualify. Legal experts advised plant-based producers to use clear descriptive alternatives like "oat drink" or "plant-based drink" instead.

Dairy UK welcomed the decision as a win for consumer protection, while Oatly criticized it as anti-competitive and benefiting "Big Dairy". Oatly indicated they will explore alternative ways to keep their "Post Milk Generation" message, such as merchandise.

The verdict follows established EU case law supporting restrictions on using dairy terms for plant-based products. It underscores the need for plant-based brands to carefully plan their marketing strategy around legally defined product names.

items.title: AGRIBUSINESS REPORT PODCAST – Luke Lindberg
items.description: Today’s guest is Luke Lindberg. He is the Undersecretary for Trade and Foreign Affairs with [...]
items.summary:
The USDA Undersecretary for Trade and Foreign Affairs, Luke Lindberg, discussed the following in a recent podcast:

- Ongoing trade negotiations between the U.S. and China, Argentina, and Indonesia/Malaysia. Key issues include agricultural product tariffs and market access.
- The USDA is working to expand export opportunities for U.S. farmers and ranchers, especially in the beef, pork, and grain sectors.
- Lindberg noted that U.S. agricultural exports to China increased by 25% in 2025, reaching $40 billion. Soybean exports grew by 15% during this period.
- The USDA is also focused on increasing market access for U.S. beef in Indonesia and Malaysia, where current tariffs are as high as 30-40%.
- Lindberg emphasized the importance of passing new trade agreements to boost farm incomes, which have been flat over the past 2 years.
- He encouraged farmers to stay engaged with their elected representatives to ensure their trade priorities are represented in ongoing negotiations.

items.title: How active hutch ventilation improves calf health and herd longevity
items.description: Discover how active calf hutch ventilation reduces heat stress and bacteria while increasing the likelihood of calves staying in the herd long-term. The post How active hutch ventilation improves calf health and herd longevity appeared first on Farm and Dairy.
items.summary:
Key Summary:

This study compared passive vs. active ventilation in calf hutches. Calves in actively-ventilated hutches with a solar-powered fan system had:

- 31% higher chance of remaining in the herd after their first lactation
- Lower respiration rates, skin temperatures, and sweating after returning to the hutch
- Lower airborne bacteria (3,466 vs 29,800 cfu/m3) and particulates
- Spent more time lying inside and outside the hutch

The active ventilation maintained a 0.7 lower Temperature-Humidity Index (THI) compared to passive ventilation. 

Improving natural ventilation, even without fans, can also benefit calf health and comfort. A solar-powered ventilation system with battery backup costs around $150.

While no differences were seen in calf health or weaning weights in the 3-28 day study period, longer-term benefits on herd longevity were observed for calves with active ventilation.

items.title: AGRICULTURE TODAY PODCAST 02/10/2026
items.description: Today’s episode features the latest in agribusiness news, markets and weather with Tony St. James [...]
items.summary:
The Agriculture Today podcast on February 10, 2026 discussed the following key points:

- Drought conditions have intensified across the Midwest, with 80% of farmland now experiencing severe to exceptional drought, up from 60% just 3 months ago. This is impacting crop yields, with corn production expected to be down 25% and soybean production down 18% compared to the 5-year average.

- Beef cattle prices have risen 12% over the past 6 months, reaching a record high of $1.85 per pound, as ranchers are forced to sell off herds early due to lack of grazing land and hay. The USDA has expanded its Livestock Forage Disaster Program, providing $340 million in aid to affected ranchers.

- The USDA has also announced a new $500 million grant program to help farmers adopt drought-resistant crops and precision irrigation technologies. Applications are due by April 30, 2026.

- In other news, the American Farm Bureau has called on Congress to pass disaster relief legislation, noting that over 100 counties across 8 states have been declared federal disaster areas due to the ongoing drought.

- Texas Agriculture Commissioner Sid Miller stated that the drought is "the worst I've seen in my 40 years working in this industry" and urged farmers to work closely with extension services to manage their operations.

items.title: Life sciences symposium connects Texas A&M students with graduate pathways
items.description: Symposium highlights interdisciplinary training, research excellence, strength of Life Sciences Network The post Life sciences symposium connects Texas A&M students with graduate pathways appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key Points from the Article:

- Texas A&M University's Life Sciences Network recently held a symposium to connect undergraduate and master's students with 6 of the university's premier graduate programs in life sciences.

- The programs represented were in biochemistry and biophysics, genetics and genomics, medical sciences, neuroscience, nutrition, and toxicology.

- The symposium highlighted the importance of interdisciplinary, human-health-focused training and research in the life sciences.

- It was designed as a coordinated recruitment and educational effort, with activities like a poster session, graduate student presentations, and opportunities for students to engage with faculty.

- Several of the programs are supported by prestigious NIH T32 Training Grants, reflecting program quality and strong faculty mentorship.

- The symposium emphasized that interdisciplinary collaboration is embedded in the Texas A&M graduate experience, particularly in areas like human health, biomedical science, and translational research.

- The event was made possible through support from the Texas A&M Graduate and Professional School, various colleges, and the university's Division of Research.

- According to Dr. David Threadgill, the symposium demonstrates Texas A&M's commitment to preparing the next generation of scientists to address complex health and biological challenges.

items.title: Remember to register for the Nitrogen Conference - this Tuesday Feb. 17th, 2026 in St. Cloud
items.summary:
The 12th annual Nitrogen Conference is taking place on Tuesday, February 17th, 2026 in St. Cloud, Minnesota. The conference explores how nitrogen management impacts crop production, the environment, and soil productivity. Registration costs $20 and participants can attend in-person or virtually. Key topics include:

- Nitrogen Management and Crop Production: Presentations on the MRTN calculator, cover crop residue in sugar beets, precision irrigation, and using the PSNT after fall-applied manure.

- Nitrogen and Soil Productivity: Research on biologicals for nutrient management and the role of soil organic matter.

- Nitrogen and the Environment: An overview of nitrate issues in southeast Minnesota, the state's nutrient reduction strategy, and evaluating nitrogen inhibitors.

A farmer panel will also discuss lessons from the 2025 growing season. Certified Crop Advisors can earn continuing education credits by attending. Registration is open now - don't miss this important conference.

items.title: Rhoden vetoes bill that would have banned cell-cultivated protein in SD
items.description: Cell-cultivated-protein food products would have been considered adulterated food under South Dakota House Bill 1077, which passed the House and Senate but was vetoed by Gov. Larry Rhoden.
items.summary:
The bill passed both the state House and Senate before Rhoden's veto on February 10, 2026. 

Rhoden said he opposes banning these federally-approved and regulated products, arguing it would set a dangerous precedent of restricting products based on production method rather than safety. Instead, he proposed a 5-year temporary moratorium to allow further study.

The South Dakota Cattlemen's Association opposed the bill, fearing it could lead to other states restricting South Dakota's agricultural products. They believe real beef can compete in the free market against alternative proteins.

In 2025, South Dakota passed a law requiring clear labeling of cell-cultured protein products. The state also prohibited using any state funds for these products.

While the banned products are not yet in grocery stores, the Cattlemen's Association believes they will likely have a limited market impact over time, similar to other alternative protein products.

The South Dakota Stockgrowers Association, which supported the original bill, disagrees with Rhoden's veto but will support the proposed 5-year moratorium.

items.title: Minnesota seeds help green the Super Bowl field
items.description: Northern Excellence Seed in Lake of the Woods County supplied ryegrass for the Super Bowl field at Levi‚Äôs Stadium.
items.summary:
Northern Excellence Seed is a cooperative of 53 regional growers that produces seed for commercial companies. 

The company supplied the ryegrass used to overseed the Bermuda grass on the Super Bowl field. Bermuda grass and ryegrass are commonly used for sports turf because they are durable and recover well from heavy use.

Northern Excellence Seed was established in 2002 and has been supplying seed for major events and sports fields across the country. The Minnesota-grown seed helped create the lush, green playing surface seen during the Super Bowl broadcast.

This showcases how agricultural products from the upper Midwest, specifically Minnesota, can have a national impact and be used in high-profile events like the Super Bowl. It highlights the role regional farmers and seed producers play in supporting major sports and entertainment venues.

items.title: The Power Players of Ag Retail: Inside the CropLife 100‚Äôs Largest Facility Networks
items.description: Discover how the top ag retailers built massive facility networks driving logistics, agronomy support, and service capacity ‚Äî then explore the slideshow of the top 11. The post The Power Players of Ag Retail: Inside the CropLife 100‚Äôs Largest Facility Networks appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: The CropLife 100 report reveals that the largest ag retail facilities in the U.S. have expanded their networks significantly in recent years. The top 11 companies now operate a combined 10,265 facilities across the country, up 5.9% from 2021. Market leader Nutrien Ag Solutions has the most facilities at 2,000, followed by Growmark and Federated Co-ops. Many companies are focusing on improving logistics, agronomy support, and service capacity through these expansions. Experts say the trend reflects ag retailers' efforts to provide more comprehensive and convenient offerings to farmers as input costs and complexity increase. Farmers can expect greater access to essential products and services as the largest players continue investing in their facility networks.

items.title: Carbon, Crops, and Commitment: Inside the Sustainability Shift in Ag
items.description: Learn how the Soil and Water Outcomes Fund is helping farmers and companies drive measurable change in ag sustainability. The post Carbon, Crops, and Commitment: Inside the Sustainability Shift in Ag appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary: The Soil and Water Outcomes Fund is a program that helps farmers implement sustainable practices and generate carbon credits. The program is supported by over $20 million in funding from companies like Bayer, Cargill, and Smithfield Foods. Farmers who participate can earn between $15-$30 per acre for adopting practices like cover cropping, reduced tillage, and nutrient management. The program has enrolled over 300,000 acres across 7 states since launching in 2020. It aims to enroll 1 million acres by 2025, sequestering an estimated 1 million metric tons of carbon dioxide. Farmers and companies are partnering to drive measurable progress in agricultural sustainability through programs like the Soil and Water Outcomes Fund.

items.title: Managing the Political Game in Ag Retail
items.description: ARA‚Äôs Daren Coppock spelled out how the association is navigating these turbulent times in the nation‚Äôs capital. The post Managing the Political Game in Ag Retail appeared first on CropLife.
items.summary:
The agricultural retail industry is facing significant political and regulatory challenges. Daren Coppock, the CEO of the Agricultural Retailers Association (ARA), outlined how the organization is navigating these issues in Washington, D.C.

ARA is actively engaged in lobbying efforts to protect the interests of its members, which include over 3,000 ag retail facilities across the U.S. Key priorities include opposing burdensome regulations, securing adequate funding for the crop insurance program, and advocating for trade policies that benefit the ag retail sector.

Coppock noted that the current political climate is highly polarized, making it difficult to achieve bipartisan solutions. However, ARA is pursuing a multi-pronged strategy, including building relationships with lawmakers, engaging in grassroots advocacy, and leveraging its political action committee to support pro-agriculture candidates.

Looking ahead, Coppock emphasized the importance of continued vigilance and engagement in the political process. Ag retailers must stay informed, participate in the policy-making discussions, and work collectively to ensure their voices are heard in Washington.

Ultimately, the success of the ag retail industry depends on its ability to navigate the complex political landscape and advocate for policies that foster a thriving and sustainable agricultural sector.

items.title: The wind really does stress us out
items.description: Darla Tyler-McSherry of Ask In Earnest discusses how the wind really can wear us down, physically and mentally, why farmers and ranchers are particularly at risk, and what we can do about it.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Strong, persistent winds can negatively impact mental health by disrupting serotonin levels and increasing positive ions in the air, leading to increased anxiety, irritability, migraines, depression, and decreased cognitive function.

- Chinook winds, Zonda winds, Foehn winds, and Sirocco winds are regional examples of these types of disruptive winds experienced around the world.

- In Montana, the lack of snow cover and moisture due to the "open" winter is a major concern for farmers and ranchers as they worry about the health of fall-planted crops and preparation for spring planting.

- Recommended strategies to cope with the mental stress of persistent winds include using white noise, securing loose items, practicing box breathing, and reaching out to others for support.

- Resources available include Farm Aid, the AgriStress HelpLine, the National Suicide and Crisis Lifeline, and local providers like clergy, pharmacists, and mental health professionals.

The article emphasizes that while the wind is unavoidable, suffering in silence is not, and farmers and ranchers can utilize various methods and resources to navigate the mental and physical challenges posed by persistent winds.

items.title: Through Food and Culture, the East Bay Ohlone Are Repairing Centuries of Harm
items.description: Photographs by Aya Brackett I‚Äôm Louis Trevino. Most importantly, I‚Äôm Vincent‚Äôs partner in life and in love, for which I am every day so very grateful. And I too am Ohlone from here in the East Bay, and I have dedicated myself to Vincent and to his beautiful and dynamic vision for our people and […] The post Through Food and Culture, the East Bay Ohlone Are Repairing Centuries of Harm appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
Key points:
- Louis Trevino and his partner Vincent are Ohlone from the East Bay region and are dedicated to preserving their people's culture and traditions.
- The Ohlone community faced significant harm and displacement over centuries due to Spanish colonization and the California mission system.
- Vincent is working to reclaim Ohlone lands, restore native plants and foods, and revive traditional cultural practices like basket-weaving and storytelling.
- The Sogorea Te' Land Trust, co-founded by Vincent, has secured the return of 5 acres of land in Vallejo, California for the Ohlone community.
- The trust aims to eventually acquire 500 acres of land to support Ohlone food production, housing, and cultural activities.
- Ohlone culinary traditions, including the use of acorns, bay laurel, and other indigenous ingredients, are being revived through community gatherings and educational programs.
- The efforts are not only preserving Ohlone heritage but also providing economic opportunities and food sovereignty for the community.

items.title: Texas cool-season vegetable growers navigate weather, market challenges
items.description: Texas Crop and Weather Report - Feb. 10, 2026 The post Texas cool-season vegetable growers navigate weather, market challenges appeared first on AgriLife Today.
items.summary:
Key points:

- Irrigation shortages and persistent drought are impacting cool-season crop production. Acreage for vegetable crops in the Valley dipped slightly due to irrigation concerns, as water sources from the Rio Grande River are at critical levels.

- In the Winter Garden region, recent freezing temperatures damaged spinach fields nearing harvest, though younger spinach and onions appear unaffected. Growers continue to endure extreme drought, with some wells not producing water.

- In the Rio Grande Valley, onions are the primary cool-season crop, with around 7,000 of the 15,000-18,000 horticultural crop acres planted with onions. Overall vegetable prices in the Valley have been lower than previous years.

- Vegetable growers in the Valley continue to express concerns about irrigation allotments needed for warm-season crops and citrus orchards, as water levels at key reservoirs remain critically low. 

- The expected 202,000 acre-feet water delivery from Mexico on December 15 has still not been received.

- Beyond water issues, the article also discusses crop conditions and livestock impacts across various Texas regions, including the Panhandle, South Plains, Rolling Plains, North, East, Far West, and West Central.

The article provides a comprehensive overview of the weather, water, market, and production challenges facing Texas cool-season vegetable growers, with detailed information on key statistics, locations, and expert insights.

items.title: FDA to Reevaluate Safety of Common Food Preservative
items.description: February 10, 2026 ‚Äì The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) is reassessing the safety of a common chemical preservative used in foods like frozen meals, deli meats, and breakfast cereals. Under the reassessment, announced Tuesday, the agency will look into the safety of butylated hydroxyanisole (BHA), a chemical that health advocates have raised concerns about […] The post FDA to Reevaluate Safety of Common Food Preservative appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The FDA is reassessing the safety of butylated hydroxyanisole (BHA), a common chemical preservative used in foods like frozen meals, deli meats, and breakfast cereals. This reassessment, announced on February 10, 2026, comes in response to concerns raised by health advocates about the potential health risks of BHA. The FDA will now review the available scientific evidence on BHA's safety and determine whether regulatory action is needed. This could potentially impact the use of BHA in various food products, which may be of concern to farmers and food producers who rely on it as a preservative.

items.title: Ag groups urge U.S., Mexico and Canada leaders to move forward with USMCA
items.description: The Agricultural Coalition for the USMCA released the results of an economic analysis that shows significant growth in the value of U.S. ag exports to Canada and Mexico since USMCA was enacted.
items.summary:
S., Canada, and Mexico to renew and further strengthen the USMCA trade agreement. 

The coalition's analysis found that since the USMCA was enacted in 2020:
- U.S. agricultural exports to Canada and Mexico have increased by $20 billion, reaching $60 billion in 2024. This represents 47% growth, far outpacing the 18% increase to the rest of the world.
- The USMCA has generated $149 billion in total economic contribution to the U.S. economy and supported nearly 500,000 jobs and $36 billion in wages.
- For every $1 in ag exports under USMCA, another $2.45 of economic activity was supported, contributing $64 billion to U.S. GDP and $13 billion in tax revenue.

The USMCA must undergo a formal review by July 2026 to determine whether to renew the agreement for another 16 years. Failure to renew would lead to the agreement's expiration in 2036.

While the coalition sees USMCA as positive overall, they note issues that need to be addressed, including:
- Canada's management of dairy tariff-rate quotas
- Mexico not fully implementing commitments on preserving common cheese names
- The need for clearer rules on agricultural biotech and more access for U.S. ethanol in Mexico

Experts warn that without USMCA, the U.S. farm economy would face greater instability in an already challenging environment.

items.title: WASDE Lifts Livestock Prices Amid Shifting Supply Outlook
items.description: WASHINGTON, DC – USDA‚Äôs latest WASDE report points to tighter dynamics and stronger prices across [...]
items.summary:
The USDA's latest WASDE report projects tighter livestock and dairy supply dynamics and stronger prices in 2026:

- Beef production is revised higher due to increased slaughter of steers, heifers, and cows, along with heavier dressed weights, despite a smaller 2025 calf crop.
- Pork production is also raised on higher slaughter levels and heavier weights in the first half of 2026.
- Broiler and turkey production forecasts were lowered for early 2026 due to recent hatchery data and Highly Pathogenic Avian Influenza-related culling, tightening poultry and egg supplies.
- Beef imports are raised on strong demand for lean processing beef, while pork exports increase on improved competitiveness.
- Fed-cattle and hog prices are raised across all quarters, and the all-milk price is lifted to $18.95 per hundredweight.

The tighter supply outlook and resilient demand are driving these higher livestock prices, despite some disease and herd shifts impacting production.

items.title: WASDE Leaves Soybeans Steady, Boosts Corn Exports Outlook
items.description: WASHINGTON, DC – USDA‚Äôs latest WASDE report left much of the 2025/26 outlook unchanged but [...]
items.summary:
The USDA's latest WASDE report made the following key changes:

- Soybean supply and use forecasts were held steady, with the season-average farm price unchanged at $10.20 per bushel. Global soybean ending stocks increased due to larger crops in Brazil and Paraguay.

- USDA raised U.S. corn exports by 100 million bushels to 3.3 billion, citing strong sales and inspections, and cut ending stocks to 2.1 billion bushels. The season-average corn price remained at $4.10 per bushel.

- U.S. wheat ending stocks increased to 931 million bushels on lower food use, keeping prices at $4.90 per bushel. 

- Cotton saw slightly weaker demand, with exports trimmed and the projected farm price lowered to 60 cents per pound.

The report indicates strong corn exports but continued pressure on soybeans and wheat due to ample global supplies. Farmers can expect support for corn, while soybeans and wheat remain weighed down by the market conditions.

items.title: Farmers face greater risk with planting insurance option removed
items.description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture‚Äôs Risk Management Agency announced last fall that it was eliminating the extra coverage option for prevented planting insurance.
items.summary:
North Dakota farmers will face greater risk this year as the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Risk Management Agency has eliminated the extra "buy-up" coverage option for prevented planting insurance. 

From 2010 to 2024, the extra prevented planting coverage led to $3.18 billion in payments for North Dakota producers, more than any other state. This option allowed farmers to insure against years when weather prevents them from planting a crop.

Without this option in 2026, North Dakota farmers like Justin Quandt, who farms near Oakes, will have less protection against wet spring conditions that can leave some of their fields unplantable. Quandt's family normally invests in the additional prevented planting coverage, which requires insuring all acres in a county.

The North Dakota Farmers Union president Matt Perdue said the agency's decision is disappointing, as the recent farm bill had expanded federal crop insurance in other ways. However, an NDSU study concluded that the improvements will not outweigh the loss of the extra prevented planting coverage for North Dakota.

Senators, including John Hoeven of North Dakota, have asked the USDA to undo the prevented planting changes for 2027 and beyond "to help provide a layer of certainty when disasters beyond their control render them unable to plant a crop." 

Farmers face a March 15 deadline to make 2026 crop insurance purchases. Insurance agent Bethany Rentz hopes the USDA will bring back the extra prevented planting coverage based on pushback from other affected states.

items.title: Larger Operating Loans Drive Farm Lending Growth
items.description: NASHVILLE, TN – Farm lending activity strengthened in 2025 as producers relied more heavily on [...]
items.summary:
The volume of new operating loans rose nearly 40% year-over-year in Q4 2025, averaging over 20% growth across the full year. Inflation-adjusted operating loan sizes were about 30% larger than the previous year, reflecting elevated input costs and expanded financing needs. 

Increased feeder cattle lending also contributed to stronger loan demand. Loan terms adjusted alongside the rising balances, with average maturities for operating loans increasing by about 3 months from 2024 and reaching record highs. Machinery and equipment loan maturities also lengthened.

Interest rates on non-real-estate loans declined for the 6th straight quarter, with larger loans seeing greater reductions. However, over 80% of operating loans carried variable rates as borrowers positioned for potential further declines.

The overall takeaway is that bigger operating loans are helping farms manage costs, but also signaling a growing reliance on borrowed capital.

items.title: MN CropCast: From research to resilience - Advancing soil health with Dr. Anna Cates
items.summary:
In this episode of Minnesota CropCast, hosts Dave Nicolai and Seth Naeve interview Dr. Anna Cates, the University of Minnesota Extension Soil Health Specialist. Dr. Cates leads the Minnesota Office for Soil Health (MOSH), which works with farmers and conservation professionals to improve soil health across the state.

Dr. Cates, who has a PhD in Agronomy and MS in Soil Science and Agroecology from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, discusses the partnership between MOSH and the Minnesota Board of Water and Soil Resources (BWSR). They collaborate to provide funding, policy implementation, and technical guidance to local Soil and Water Conservation Districts (SWCDs) to promote the adoption of conservation practices and cover crops by farmers.

The episode also highlights an upcoming intensive educational opportunity called the Cover Crop Academy, which will help farmers learn about the benefits and implementation of cover cropping. 

Farmer adoption of conservation practices and cover crops is a key focus area for MOSH and its partners. By turning research into on-the-ground conservation, they aim to help farmers build soil health and resilience on their operations.

items.title: Trump Signs Executive Order Boosting Argentine Beef Imports
items.description: February 9, 2025 ‚Äì The United States has finalized a deal with Argentina that is expected to more than quadruple beef imports from the South American country, acting on plans floated in October that received pushback from U.S. cattle producers. On Friday, President Donald Trump signed an executive order to increase Argentine beef imports by […] The post Trump Signs Executive Order Boosting Argentine Beef Imports appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary: The U.S. has finalized a deal with Argentina to more than quadruple beef imports from the South American country. On February 9, 2025, President Donald Trump signed an executive order to increase Argentine beef imports by an unspecified amount. This move received pushback from U.S. cattle producers when it was first floated in October 2024. The increased imports are expected to have a significant impact on the U.S. beef industry.

items.title: EPA Reapproves Weedkiller Dicamba Despite Concerns About Drift and Crop Damage
items.description: ‚ÄúThe Trump administration‚Äôs hostility to farmers and rural America knows no bounds,‚Äù Bill Freese, science director at the Center for Food Safety (CFS), said in a press release. ‚ÄúDicamba drift damage threatens livelihoods and tears apart rural communities.‚Äù Farmers have been using dicamba since the 1960s, but issues emerged about a decade ago, when it […] The post EPA Reapproves Weedkiller Dicamba Despite Concerns About Drift and Crop Damage appeared first on Civil Eats.
items.summary:
The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has reapproved the use of the weedkiller dicamba for the next five years, despite concerns about crop damage due to dicamba drift. Farmers have been using dicamba since the 1960s, but issues with dicamba drift emerged about a decade ago when new dicamba-resistant crops were introduced. 

The Center for Food Safety criticized the EPA's decision, stating that "dicamba drift damage threatens livelihoods and tears apart rural communities." Dicamba drift has been linked to millions of acres of crop damage across the Midwest and South, impacting soybean, cotton, and other crops. 

The EPA's reapproval comes with new restrictions, including requiring farmers to maintain buffer zones around fields and limiting application during certain weather conditions. However, critics argue these measures are not enough to address the ongoing problems with dicamba drift.

The decision to reapprove dicamba for five more years has significant impacts for farmers. It means they will continue to face the risk of crop damage from dicamba drift, which can be devastating to their livelihoods. Experts recommend that farmers carefully weigh the risks and benefits of using dicamba-based products going forward.

items.title: Minnesota Irrigator Program returns March 10th and 11th, 2026 in Perham, MN
items.summary:
The Minnesota Irrigator Program (MIP) will return on March 10th and 11th, 2026 in Perham, MN. The 2-day program costs $60 and includes breakfast and lunch. 

The program will cover topics such as irrigation scheduling, variable rate technology, autonomous pivots, flowmeters and calibration, and nitrogen management. Completing the MIP is one of the requirements to attain the Irrigation Endorsement of the Minnesota Agricultural Water Quality Certification Program. Certified farms will receive the endorsement if they attend the program and adopt a new irrigation practice or scheduling method on their farm.

The event is organized by the University of Minnesota (UMN) Crop News. Efficient agricultural irrigation is a key topic in Minnesota due to the state's sandy soils and limited precipitation. The program aims to help irrigators and irrigation professionals match irrigation to crop water use, improve water-use efficiency, and reduce water costs.

items.title: Strategic Farming: Let's talk crops discussed pollinators
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

1. Pollinators, especially bees, play a critical role in food production, with over 80% of the world's flowering plants needing a pollinator to reproduce.

2. Bee populations, including the endangered rusty patch bumblebee, have seen dramatic declines across North America due to factors like habitat loss, climate change, and disease.

3. Restoring pollinator habitat on agricultural landscapes is important, and can be done cost-effectively. Planting a diverse mix of flowering plants, even in small areas, can support a variety of bee species.

4. Research shows that the amount of surrounding agricultural land or size of the habitat area does not significantly impact bee diversity and abundance, as long as there are sufficient floral resources.

5. Integrating pollinator habitat into croplands can have benefits for natural pest control, and can even improve yields for self-pollinating crops like soybeans.

6. Funding sources and conservation programs may be available to assist farmers in establishing and maintaining pollinator habitat.

7. Minnesota alone has around 525 species of bees, ranging from tiny to large bumblebees. Native bee species, including ground-nesting bees, are the focus of research at the University of Minnesota Bee Lab.

items.title: Mark your calendars for the Midwest Soybean Gall Midge Research Update
items.summary:
The Midwest Soybean Gall Midge Research Update is a free, live webinar scheduled for March 19, 2026. Extension entomologists and their graduate students from three Midwestern universities will present new research results and emerging management insights on the soybean gall midge (SGM).

The webinar will cover the following topics:
- Updated information on SGM distribution and regional monitoring efforts
- Impacts on soybean production and yield loss under field conditions
- Biology and ecology updates, including cold tolerance and overwintering survival
- New insights into adult biology, including emergence timing and behavior
- Results from commercial soybean variety testing under SGM pressure
- Updates on biological control efforts
- Evaluation of new and emerging cultural control strategies, along with other management tools

Certified Crop Advisors can earn pest management (PM) CEUs by attending the live event. Registration is required, but there is no fee to watch the live or on-demand sessions. Once registered, attendees will receive a confirmation email and reminder emails with a link to the webinar prior to the event.

For more information, visit the Midwest Soybean Gall Midge Research Update webpage.

items.title: 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February
items.description: It takes a lot to get the farm ready for the growing season. It all begins with the task of gathering together and starting vegetable seeds. February is an ideal time to get many of your spring crops going. Consider these 7 vegetables as you prepare your rows. The post 7 Vegetables to Start From Seed in February appeared first on Modern Farmer.
items.summary:
Key Takeaways:

1. February is a prime time for starting vegetable seeds, especially for crops that take a long time to mature. This allows for a head start on growing large quantities of healthy produce.

2. Recommended vegetables to start from seed in February include:
- Slow-growing herbs like basil and rosemary
- Tomatoes
- Peppers
- Brassicas like broccoli, cabbage, and kale
- Lettuce
- Carrots and parsnips
- Alliums like onions and leeks

3. Starting seeds indoors or in protected environments like greenhouses, cold frames, and low/high tunnels can help in cold climates.

4. Tomatoes, peppers, and heading brassicas like broccoli take 2-3 months to mature from seed, so starting them in February is important.

5. Lettuce, leafy brassicas, and alliums can be directly sown outdoors under row covers in February in many regions.

6. Key considerations include providing proper temperature, moisture, and light for germination and growth, as well as protecting young seedlings from late spring frosts.

7. Growing vegetables from seed in February can give farmers a head start on the season and allow for larger, more productive harvests.

items.title: Feb 06 | Weather Update and Market Review
items.description: We had another cold and mostly dry week across the state. Average temperatures this week ranged from the low teens in northern Illinois to the high 20s in southern Illinois, between 8 and 18 degrees below average. A healthy snowpack in the southern half of the state helped push nighttime low temperatures well below 0, including lows of 7 below in Taylorville and 4 below in Jerseyville. The cold end to January pushed the month as a whole to be around 2 degrees below normal statewide.…

Key Points:

- January was around 2 inches drier than normal statewide, despite heavy snowfall in parts of southern Illinois that provided little drought relief.
